channel.title: RSS CBC World
channel.description: Articles: a comprehensive guide for the most recent international stories and headlines

item.title: South Korea ferry: all 15 crew members linked to disaster in custody
item.description: South Korean officials have now detained the entire navigating crew of the ferry that sank earlier this month. The 15 crew members, including the captain, are accused of negligence and failing to help passengers in need.

item.title: Atari's E.T. The Extraterrestrial games to be dug out of landfill
item.description: Hidden for three decades in a landfill deep in the New Mexico desert lie thousands of Atari cartridges from what is widely believed to be worst video game ever made — or so the urban legend goes.

item.title: 6 ways to fix 'maxed out' Everest
item.description: National Geographic contributor and Everest climber Mark Jenkins proposes six ways to solve the problems with Mount Everest.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: G7 imposes more sanctions on Russia
item.description: G7 leaders announced Friday that they will be imposing additional sanctions on Russia over the ongoing crisis in Ukraine.

item.title: Airbus tests prototype of electric airplane
item.description: Airbus successfully tested a prototype electric plane, dubbed the E-Fan, in Bordeaux, France, Friday. Click on the video to see footage from the test flight.

item.title: 4 Paris policemen arrested over alleged rape of Canadian woman
item.description: French media report four police officers are in custody in connection with the alleged rape of a Canadian woman at the Paris police headquarters.

item.title: North Korea detains U.S. tourist it says tore up passport and claimed asylum
item.description: North Korea has detained a 24-year-old American man for improper behaviour while he was being processed to enter the country as a tourist, state media reported Saturday.

item.title: South Korea ferry: Some children's bodies misidentified
item.description: As visiting President Barack Obama offers South Koreans his condolences for the ferry disaster, the South Korean government concedes that some bodies have been misidentified and announces changes to prevent such mistakes from happening again.

item.title: Barack Obama weighs tougher North Korea sanctions
item.description: In a display of unity against North Korea's provocations, U.S. President Barack Obama and South Korean President Park Geun-hye warned Pyongyang on Friday that it could face tougher sanctions if it follows through with threats to launch a fourth nuclear test.

item.title: The net neutrality battle for equal access vs. pay-for-premium internet
item.description: Brazil, Europe have taken an open internet stance, while the U.S. seems to be veering in the opposite direction. What will Canada do?

item.title: Elon Musk's salary as Tesla CEO was $70,000 in 2013
item.description: Tesla Motors CEO Elon Musk was paid just under $70,000 in 2013 — barely enough to buy one of his company's cars — but lucrative stock options could see him cash in millions if the company hits certain long-term objectives.

item.title: Prince George ends Australia tour with Will and Kate
item.description: Britain's Prince William and his wife, Kate, ended their 10-day tour of Australia on Friday with veterans' day commemorations in the national capital.

item.title: Airbus tests prototype electric airplane
item.description: Airbus successfully tested a prototype electric plane, dubbed the E-Fan, in Bordeaux, France, Friday. Click on the video to see footage from the test flight.

item.title: Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370: seabed search set to widen
item.description: The seabed search for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet is set to widen as a sonar scan of the most likely crash site deep beneath the Indian Ocean nears completion without yielding a single clue, authorities say.

item.title: Syria conflict: U.K. police urge Muslim women to stop would-be extremists
item.description: British counterterrorism police have launched an unprecedented appeal to Muslim women, urging them to dissuade relatives from travelling to Syria to fight with extremist Islamist groups and to report any concerns about their family members’ intentions.

item.title: Keystone XL protesters get wet, but not arrested, in D.C.
item.description: Members of the Cowboy and Indian Alliance managed to pull off an anti-Keystone XL pipeline protest in the reflecting pool that lies in front of the famous Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C., on Thursday without getting arrested.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: Lavrov accuses West of plotting to seize control
item.description: Accusing the West of plotting to control Ukraine, Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov declared Friday that the pro-Russia insurgents in eastern Ukraine will only lay down their arms if the Ukrainian government clears out the Maidan protest camp in Kyiv.

item.title: Israel suspends Mideast peace talks over Fatah's reconciliation with Hamas
item.description: Israel's security cabinet agrees to shelve the negotiations as the result of a new deal struck by the Palestinian Authority to create a reconciliation government with the militant group Hamas

item.title: Simon Ostrovsky, U.S. journalist held in Ukraine, now free
item.description: Simon Ostrovsky, the U.S. journalist who was being held by pro-Russian gunmen in eastern Ukraine, was freed Thursday.

item.title: Net neutrality plan would lead to two-speed internet: Don Pittis
item.description: The FCC's recent musings on ending net neutrality could spell the end of what makes the internet great — that it's an all-you-can-eat buffet for some, but an occasional delicacy for others, Don Pittis writes.

item.title: Malaysia Airlines MH370: seabed search set to widen
item.description: The seabed search for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet is set to widen as a sonar scan of the most likely crash site deep beneath the Indian Ocean nears completion without yielding a single clue, authorities said on Friday.

item.title: Bangladesh's Rana Plaza factory collapse spurs change, finger-pointing
item.description: A year after the deadly Rana Plaza factory collapse in Bangladesh, families of the thousands of workers affected are still struggling with the emotional and economic fallout.

item.title: Michael Pineda suspended 10 games for pine tar use
item.description: New York Yankees pitcher Michael Pineda was suspended for 10 games Thursday after being caught using pine tar. He said he won't appeal the penalty that will cost him two starts.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: Russia's credit rating cut by S&P
item.description: The Standard & Poor's credit agency on Friday cut Russia's credit rating for the first time in more than five years, raising the financial stakes flowing from the crisis in Ukraine as tensions rise and the United States and its allies are contemplating further economic sanctions.

item.title: Measles cases hit record levels in U.S.; vaccinations encouraged
item.description: Measles cases are at their highest level in the U.S. for this point in the year since 1996, so public health officials are urging parents to vaccinate children and are reminding health-care providers about how to recognize the illness.

item.title: Mount Everest climbing season in disarray as expedition teams cancel
item.description: Nepal's attempts to salvage the Mount Everest climbing season fell flat Thursday as major expedition companies cancelled their climbs and many Sherpas quit the mountain after an avalanche killed 16 of their fellow guides last week.

item.title: Australian pilot reports hijack attempt on flight to Bali
item.description: The pilot of a Virgin Australia plane flying to the Indonesian holiday island of Bali reported a hijacking attempt on Friday after a passenger tried to enter the cockpit, an Indonesian transport official said.

item.title: Ukraine clashes kill 2 as Russia ramps up military exercises
item.description: Ukrainian forces moved in and killed at least two pro-Russia insurgents in the country's tumultuous east Thursday, an escalation that prompted new threats from Russian President Vladimir Putin.

item.title: Israel suspends Mideast peace talks citing Palestinian pact with Hamas
item.description: Israel's security cabinet agrees to shelve the negotiations as the result of a new deal struck by the Palestinian Authority to create a reconciliation government with the militant group Hamas

item.title: Measles 'early and active' in U.S.
item.description: Measles cases are at their highest level in the U.S. for this point in the year since 1996, so public health officials are urging parents to vaccinate children and are reminding health-care providers about how to recognize the illness.

item.title: South Korea ferry: Families' anger grows as search goes on
item.description: Angry relatives of some of the more than 120 people still missing from the sinking of the ferry Sewol surrounded the fisheries minister and the coast guard chief Thursday, preventing them from leaving the area where families have been waiting for word of their loved ones for more than a week.

item.title: Prince Charles, Camilla devastated over Mark Shand's death
item.description: The Prince of Wales and his wife, Camilla, are "utterly devastated" by the death of her brother, who fell outside a hotel bar, suffering a head injury.

item.title: Madeleine McCann case: U.K. police probe more break-ins
item.description: British police investigating the disappearance of Madeleine McCann say they are looking into more cases involving sexual assaults on children in the area where the girl, then four years old, vanished.

item.title: Congo train derailment kills at least 50, authorities say
item.description: Officials in Congo say a freight train has derailed in the country's southeast, killing at least 50 people.

item.title: U.S. journalist Simon Ostrovsky, held in Ukraine, now free and safe
item.description: Simon Ostrovsky, the U.S. journalist who was being held by pro-Russian gunmen in eastern Ukraine, is free and safe, a Radio-Canada journalist says.

item.title: Car bomb kills 4 outside Nairobi police station
item.description: Police in Kenya's capital, Nairobi, intercepted a suspicious car at a traffic light Wednesday before it exploded, killing four people, including two police officers.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: Russia announces military exercises near border
item.description: Russia's defence minister announces new military exercises along the Ukrainian border just hours after Ukrainian troops killed at least two pro-Russia insurgents in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Afghanistan hospital guard kills 3 U.S. doctors
item.description: The U.S. Embassy in Afghanistan says three doctors killed by an Afghan security guard at a Kabul hospital are American citizens.

item.title: The Koch brothers: Who are they and why do Democrats hate them?
item.description: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid is leading the charge by Democrats against America's richest brothers, Charles and David Koch, accusing them of trying to "buy democracy" through their generous funding of political campaigns. Reid calls them "oil baron bullies" and he's on a mission to discredit them.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: Putin threatens Kyiv after military operation kills 2
item.description: Ukrainian government troops moved against pro-Russia forces in the east of the country and killed at least two of them in clashes at checkpoints manned by the insurgents. Russian President Vladimir Putin called it a "grave crime" and threatened Kyiv with unspecified consequences.

item.title: Ukraine clashes between military, pro-Russia insurgents kill 2
item.description: The Ukrainian government and pro-Russia insurgents report at least two deaths on the pro-Russia side during clashes in east Ukraine.

item.title: South Sudan conflict: UN denies turning away massacre victims
item.description: The United Nations mission in South Sudan accused the government Wednesday of spreading false claims that the UN camp near the scene of a massacre refused to shelter victims.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: Harper to send up to 500 election monitors
item.description: Canada will send up to 500 people to monitor Ukraine's presidential election next month, Prime Minister Stephen Harper says.

item.title: Afghanistan hospital guard kills 3 foreign doctors
item.description: An Afghan security guard opened fire on a group of doctors at a Kabul hospital on Thursday morning, killing three foreign physicians and wounding two other people, officials said.

item.title: Afghanistan hospital attack kills 3 foreigners
item.description: Police in Afghanistan say a security guard has opened fire in a Kabul hospital, killing three foreigners and wounding one other person.

item.title: Stacey Armato promised $75K US in compensation over breast-milk airport screening
item.description: Woman who was held at a Phoenix airport four years ago after refusing to have her breast milk X-rayed has reached a tentative settlement with the U.S. Transportation Security Administration.

item.title: Malaysia Airlines MH370: Material on Australian shore not from jet
item.description: Unidentified material that washed ashore in southwestern Australia that was examined for any link to the lost Malaysian plane is not from the jet.

item.title: Everest avalanche: How a Sherpa strike will affect Nepal's tourist industry
item.description: A walkout by Sherpa mountain climbers following the tragic deaths of 16 guides on Mount Everest will certainly have an impact on the Nepalese economy. High-altitude mountaineering and the industry that supports it are crucial parts of the area's tourism.

item.title: Amazon snares classic HBO shows in deal
item.description: Fans of classic HBO shows like The Sopranos and The Wire will soon have access to those series and more through Amazon's Prime service in the first online streaming deal signed by the cable network.

item.title: Stacey Armato to get $75K US in compensation over breast-milk airport screening
item.description: Woman who was held at a Phoenix airport four years ago after refusing to have her breast milk X-rayed has reached a tentative settlement with the U.S. Transportation Security Administration.

item.title: New York police face backlash for #myNYPD photo campaign
item.description: A public outreach campaign by the New York City Police Department has backfired — in a very public way. Its call-out to Twitter users to share pictures of themselves interacting with police officers using the hashtag #myNYPD brought in a flood of photos of police brutality instead of the friendlier images the department was hoping for.

item.title: South Korea ferry: Was steering gear failure to blame?
item.description: A maritime professor who spoke with the third mate who was steering the South Korean ferry before it sank says that he suspects there was a problem with the steering gear.

item.title: Ukraine: Pro-Russia insurgents hold U.S. journalist captive
item.description: Pro-Russian gunmen in eastern Ukraine admitted on Wednesday that they are holding an American journalist, saying he was suspected of unspecified "bad activities."

item.title: Cairo bombing kills senior Egyptian police officer
item.description: Egyptian security officials say a senior police officer has died after an explosive device placed under his car went off in a western Cairo suburb.

item.title: Mount Everest expeditions cancelled due to Sherpa walkout
item.description: Dozens of Sherpa guides packed up their tents and left Mount Everest's base camp Wednesday, after the avalanche deaths of 16 of their colleagues exposed an undercurrent of resentment by Sherpas over their pay, treatment and benefits.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: Lavrov vows response if Russians attacked in Ukraine
item.description: Russia's foreign minister on Wednesday promised a firm response if its citizens or interests come under attack in Ukraine — a vow that came after Ukraine announced a renewal of its "anti-terror" campaign against those occupying buildings in its troubled east.

item.title: Mount Everest avalanche: Sherpas hold walkout at base camp
item.description: Dozens of Sherpa guides packed up their tents and left Mount Everest's base camp Wednesday, after the avalanche deaths of 16 of their colleagues exposed an undercurrent of resentment by Sherpas over their pay, treatment and benefits.

item.title: Keystone XL pipeline protesters gather in Washington
item.description: Anti-pipeline "Reject and Protect" protesters are gathering in Washington, D.C., this week to pound the Obama administration with a visual demonstration of their opposition to Keystone XL.

item.title: Malaysia Airlines MH370: Material on Australian shore examined
item.description: Unidentified material that washed ashore in southwestern Australia and is being examined for any link to the lost Malaysian plane is unlikely to have come from the jet, an official says.

item.title: Big Bang, evolution, climate change widely doubted in U.S., poll suggests
item.description: Half of Americans lack confidence in the Big Bang and 4 in 10 similarly lack confidence in scientific findings about global warming and evolution, a new poll by the Associated Press shows.

item.title: Shakespeare at 450: How science may have influenced his work
item.description: We don’t usually talk about Shakespeare and science in the same breath, but the playwright lived during a remarkable period of discovery, writes Dan Falk on the Bard of Avon's 450th birthday.

item.title: South Korea ferry: Identified deaths climb to 146
item.description: The grim work of recovering bodies from the submerged South Korea ferry proceeded rapidly Wednesday, with the official death toll reaching 146, though a government official said divers must now rip through cabin walls to retrieve more victims.

item.title: Ukraine: Acting president orders new 'anti-terror' operation
item.description: Ukraine's acting president ordered security forces to resume "anti-terror" operations in the country's east Tuesday after the bodies of two people allegedly abducted by pro-Russia insurgents were found and a military aircraft was reported to be hit by gunfire.

item.title: South Sudan conflict: Children, elderly killed in latest slaughter
item.description: Gunmen who targeted both children and the elderly left "piles and piles" of bodies — many of those in a mosque — in a provincial capital in South Sudan, the top United Nations top humanitarian official in the country said Tuesday.

item.title: Malaysia Airlines MH370: Australia to deploy powerful sonar in search
item.description: Australia may use more powerful sonar equipment that can delve deeper beneath the Indian Ocean in the hunt for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet as the prime minister said Wednesday that failure to find any clue in the most likely crash site would not spell the end of the search.

item.title: Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Nobel-winning author, hailed
item.description: Long into the night, the line of mourners stretched for nearly a mile, waiting their turn to file into Mexico City's majestic Palace of Fine Arts and bid farewell to Gabriel Garcia Marquez.

item.title: Earth Day 2014: Electric cars at a 'tipping point'
item.description: Cars powered by electricity such as the highly touted and fun-to-drive Tesla are challenging the auto industry status quo, but hurdles remain before they will displace gas vehicles on the road.

item.title: South Korea ferry crew had moments of heroism
item.description: As the South Korean ferry sank, some crew members gave their lifejackets to passengers. One refused to leave until she shepherded students off the ship, and was later found dead.

item.title: MERS alarm in Saudi Arabia heightens after 2 more deaths
item.description: Saudi Arabia's health ministry says two more patients who contracted a potentially fatal Middle East virus related to SARS have died as the kingdom detected 17 new cases of the disease.

item.title: Aereo, T.V. broadcasters battle in Supreme Court fight
item.description: The Supreme Court is taking up a dispute between broadcasters and an Internet startup company that has the potential to bring big changes to the television industry.

item.title: South Korea ferry: Identified deaths climb to 113
item.description: The confirmed death toll from the April 16 ferry-sinking off South Korea's southern coast reaches 113, with about 190 people still missing.

item.title: Everest avalanche: Sherpa guides, Nepal officials meet
item.description: Nepalese authorities were meeting with Sherpa mountain guides Tuesday in an attempt to avert a climbing strike after the deadliest avalanche ever recorded on Mount Everest killed at least 13 of the guides.

item.title: Boston Marathon: Thousands run in 1st race since bombings
item.description: "The Star-Spangled Banner" played over Boylston Street to honour American winner Meb Keflezighi, a special delight for many of the 35,000-plus runners who raced the Boston Marathon course Monday.

item.title: Syrian presidential election called for June 3 despite ongoing war
item.description: Syria called a presidential election for June 3, aiming to give President Bashar al-Assad a veneer of electoral legitimacy in the midst of a civil war that has killed more than 150,000 people and driven a third of the population from their homes.

item.title: Ukraine: Joe Biden says Russia must 'stop talking and start acting'
item.description: U.S. Vice-President Joe Biden told Ukrainian political leaders Tuesday that the United States stands with them against "humiliating threats" and encouraged them to root out corruption as they rebuild their government.

item.title: Aereo, T.V. broadcasters ready for Supreme Court fight
item.description: The Supreme Court is taking up a dispute between broadcasters and an Internet startup company that has the potential to bring big changes to the television industry.

item.title: South Sudan ethnic killings condemned by United Nations
item.description: UN human rights investigators have confirmed that hundreds of civilians were killed because of their ethnicity after rebel forces seized a disputed town in South Sudan last week, the United Nations said Monday.

item.title: South Korea ferry: Death toll tops 100
item.description: One by one, coast guard officers carried the newly arrived bodies covered in white sheets from a boat to a tent on the dock of this island, the first step in identifying a sharply rising number of corpses from a South Korean ferry that sank nearly a week ago.

item.title: Electric cars at a 'tipping point'
item.description: Cars powered by electricity such as the highly touted and fun-to-drive Tesla are challenging the auto industry status quo, but hurdles remain before they will displace gas vehicles on the road.

item.title: Teen runaway survives flight in plane's wheel well
item.description: A 16-year-old boy stowed away in the wheel well of a flight from California to Hawaii, surviving the trip halfway across the Pacific Ocean unharmed despite frigid temperatures at 11,500 metres and a lack of oxygen, FBI and airline officials said.

item.title: Ukraine: Joe Biden says U.S. stands with country against 'threats'
item.description: U.S. Vice-President Joe Biden told Ukrainian political leaders Tuesday that the United States stands with them against "humiliating threats" and encouraged them to root out corruption as they rebuild their government.

item.title: Amid MERS deaths, Saudi health minister fired
item.description: Saudi Arabia's King Abdullah sacked the country's health minister on Monday amid a spike in deaths and infections from the virus known as the Middle East respiratory syndrome, or MERS.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: Joe Biden tells Ukrainian leaders U.S. stands with them
item.description: U.S. Vice-President Joe Biden told Ukrainian political leaders Tuesday that the United States stands with them against "humiliating threats" and encouraged them to root out corruption as they rebuild their government.

item.title: Nigerian school attack leaves 234 girls missing, parents say
item.description: Parents say 234 girls are missing from the northeast Nigerian school attacked last week by Islamic extremists, up significantly from the 85 reported by education officials.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth turns 88: A royal diplomat in her 'best decade' yet
item.description: Queen Elizabeth turns 88 today, and while the long-serving monarch is slowing down, she remains a significant diplomatic force.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: Joe Biden, acting Ukrainian president meet
item.description: U.S. Vice-President Joe Biden is paying a visit to Ukraine's acting president in a high-level show of U.S. support for the embattled government.

item.title: Everest avalanche: Sherpa guides' remains cremated
item.description: Buddhist monks cremated the remains of Sherpa guides who were buried in the deadliest avalanche to hit Mount Everest, a disaster that has prompted calls for a climbing boycott by Nepal's ethnic Sherpa community.

item.title: Mount Everest jump cancelled after deadly avalanche
item.description: The Discovery Network is cancelling a daredevil's planned jump off the summit of Mount Everest in a wingsuit next month following the avalanche that killed at least 13 people on Friday.

item.title: South Korea ferry: For the families, hopes are small
item.description: Families who once dreamed of miraculous rescues now simply hope their loved ones' remains are recovered soon, before the ocean does much more damage.

item.title: Rubin 'Hurricane' Carter dead at 76
item.description: Rubin 'Hurricane' Carter, the former professional boxer who became an advocate for the wrongly convicted after spending 19 years in prison for a triple murder he didn't commit, died Sunday. He was 76.

item.title: Boston Marathon begins under tight security 1 year after bombing
item.description: The 118th Boston Marathon began this morning amid a large police presence that greeted runners and spectators who filtered in Monday morning, a year after a pair of homemade pressure-cooker bombs near the finish line killed three people and wounded more than 260.

item.title: MERS virus: 3 more deaths in Saudi Arabia
item.description: Saudi authorities say three more people who contracted a potentially fatal virus related to SARS have died amid a recent increase in infections.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth releases grinning portrait for 88th birthday
item.description: The queen will celebrate her birthday privately Monday, but will hold her annual public celebration in June

item.title: South Korea ferry: 4 crew members detained
item.description: South Korean President Park Geun-hye said Monday that the captain and some crew members of the sunken ferry committed "unforgivable, murderous behavior," while criticism of her own government's handling of the disaster grew.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: Joe Biden visiting Ukraine day after violence
item.description: U.S. Vice-President Joe Biden is heading to Ukraine to meet with leaders of the turbulent country a day after violence erupted in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Everest avalanche: Sherpas consider boycott
item.description: Buddhist monks cremated the remains of Sherpa guides who were buried in the deadliest avalanche to hit Mount Everest, a disaster that has prompted calls for a climbing boycott by Nepal's ethnic Sherpa community.

item.title: Boston Marathon under tight security 1 year after bombing
item.description: One year after a pair of homemade pressure-cooker bombs killed three people and wounded more than 260 others at the finish line of the Boston Marathon, runners started filtering in Monday morning as the sun rose over the centre of Hopkinton, where the race starts.

item.title: Ukraine crisis: Russia, Ukraine trade blame for deadly gun attack
item.description: After an Easter morning shootout at a checkpoint manned by pro-Russia insurgents in eastern Ukraine, Russia's Foreign Ministry issued a statement blaming militant Ukrainian nationalists while the Ukraine Security Service said the attack was staged by provocateurs from outside the country.

item.title: Kandahar to Carleton U.: Afghan woman's risky pursuit of education
item.description: Maryam Sahar Naqibullah, once the Canadian Forces' only female translator in Afghanistan, has followed a risky path that has taken her from a classroom held on patch of desert in Kandahar, to the halls of Ottawa's Carleton University.
